private_information: I focus on translating actions and operational constraints into PDDL operators.
Planner.goal: Define the PDDL domain that captures all required blocks world actions and constraints.

private_information: I focus on verifying the consistency of the initial setup and goal state definition based on the scenario.
Auditor.goal: Define the PDDL problem (objects, initial state, and goal) corresponding exactly to the scenario description.

orchestrator.goal: Combine the PDDL domain and problem specifications generated by the Planner and Auditor into a single, valid, solved Blocks World planning file optimized for the FastDownwards solver.

public_information: This is a standard Blocks World problem involving manipulating four colored blocks (Orange, Red, Yellow, Blue).
Available actions: Pick up a block, Unstack a block, Put down a block, Stack a block.

Operational Constraints: 1) Only one block can be held at a time. 2) Pick up/Unstack requires an empty hand. 3) Pick up requires the block to be on the table and clear. 4) Unstack requires the block to be clear and truly on top of another block. 5) Successfully picking up/unstacking results in holding the block. 6) Put down requires holding the block. 7) Stack requires holding the block being stacked and the target location (another block or table) must be clear. 8) Put down/Stack results in an empty hand. 9) Stacking B onto A makes A no longer clear.
Initial State: The hand is empty. The stack configuration is: Blue is on the Table. Yellow is on Blue. Red is on Yellow. Orange is on Red. Orange is clear.
Goal State: The Yellow block must be on top of the Orange block.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with PDDL domains (Planning Domain Definition Language). You focus on defining types, predicates, and operators. You always enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags.
You are an expert in ensuring logical consistency and defining accurate PDDL problems (Planning Domain Definition Language). You always enclose the pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags.

You are an expert with PDDL problems (Planning Domain Definition Language) specialized in combining modular definitions and generating plans optimized for the FastDownwards solver. You always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file to solve the task. You always enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags, and the pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags.
